Recap

Last week we covered the basics of html & css.

We learned that with html you markup a document with tags to give the content meaning & structure.

We learned that css is where style is applied to give a document qualities like color, typography, spacing and layout.

<!-- html gives structure -->
<p>
This is a paragraph tag. 
</p>
/* css gives style */
p{
  font-size: 32px;
  color: red;
}

The Language of Modular Design

This week

Responsive Web Design

Being responsive is about making dynamic changes to appearance of your website to accommodate different screen sizes.

You must be shapeless, formless, like water. When you pour water in a cup, it becomes the cup. When you pour water in a bottle, it becomes the bottle. When you pour water in a teapot, it becomes the teapot. Bruce Lee

How do we achieve responsive design?

  1. Identify breakpoints where your layout needs to change.
  2. Scale layout proportionally in-between the breakpoints.

Technique: Media Queries (aka breakpoints)

Conditional rules for changing a view's appearance or functionality.

Try it http://bit.ly/2mY3i7S 

p{
  color: #222;
  font-size: 32px;
  font-weight: bold;
}

@media (min-width: 1200px){ 
  p{
    font-size: 64px;
  }
}

Technique: Use fluid measurements to scale proportionally.

Fluid measurements use percentages instead of fixed pixel values.

Try it http://bit.ly/2nSMPBt

Let's look at how some people are doing responsive and what the challenges are.

The Responsive Grid

Advice for working responsive

  1. Find a prototyping tool you're comfortable working with so you can test responsive states without a developer.
  2. Avoid the waste of over-comping. Trying to maintain 2-3 alternate views for each screen you're designing for can become a productivity sinkhole.
  3. Evaluating work on a artboard won't provide the same insights as a browser or mobile phone.
  4. Don't design in waterfall; designing an entire screen in one form-factor and then moving on to the next. Instead, focus on one form factor but stop every once and awhile and consider the implications for responsive states.

Assignment : Option 1

Using codepen, create a page that describes 5 CSS Rules.

Each entry needs have the rule name, a short description of it's purpose and an example of the rule applied to an html element.

Use CSS to style the html. The page should have a clear information hierarchy and layout. You'll be evaluated on the clarity and readability of the content.

Use the MDN documentation to find the list of rules.

Look at Concise CSS's documentation as a reference for clear style and hierarchy.

css rules that will help you in your task

  • background-color
  • margin
  • padding
  • border
  • font-size
  • font-family
